page.text: Based on graphic determination, this property does not lie within a designated wetland area.
Based on graphic determination, this property does not lie within a F.E.M.A./F.I.R.M. special flood hazard
The site is located in Land Lot 160 in Fayette County, Georgia. More particularly, the site
being planned for development is located on Line Creek Drive and GA Highway 54, near
Planterra Way. The total site acreage is approximately 16.19 acres and currently contains
three office buildings, an office/warehouse, associated parking, and a cell phone tower. The
remainder of the site is currently densely grassed and wooded. The parcel will be re-
developed as a commercial property that will encompass retail businesses.
The site was previously developed with three office buildings, a warehouse/office building, and
associated parking that cover a small percentage of the site. The eastern portion of the site
houses a cellular tower and associated equipment. The remainder of the site is wooded.
Directly west of the site is the Line Creek Nature Preserve that contains an unnamed pond.
Directly south of the site is a residential subdivision. A 75 foot undisturbed buffer will be
applied along the south property line. The remainder of the site consists of mostly pervious
vegetated areas. All of the existing basins have minimal imperious areas.
The Pre-developed site is broken into 3 different drainage areas due to the existing topography
of the studied basin. Slopes vary across the site. There are two different soil types on the
property; Gwinnett sandy loam and Cecil sandy loam. Both are present in 2 to 6 percent
Existing Basin 1 consists of 7.38 acres and makes up the southwestern portion of the site. The
basin drains to the southwest corner of the site into an existing ephemeral stream which
deposits in the unnamed weathered pond directly west of the site. A 25-foot buffer will be
Existing Basin 2 consists of 2.62 acres and makes up the eastern portion of the site. The basin
drains to the east into an existing catch basin along Planterra Way.
Existing Basin 3 consists of 1.29 acres and makes up the northwestern portion of the site. The
basin drains to the west into an existing ephemeral stream which deposits in the unnamed
weathered pond directly west of the site.
The following Area Summary table shows the estimated time of concentration, CN values and
When completed, the site will contain retail areas and associated parking as well as the
existing cell phone tower. The remainder of the site will be landscaped. The proposed site
will be broken into four different drainage basins. Runoff will be captured by a proposed storm
system located throughout the site that combines and flows into an above ground water quality
pond located in the southwest corner of the site, along the western property line.
Additionally, the site discharge will be treated in on-site water quality features, located within
each basin. The pond accommodates water quality and channel protection for the basin
volume as specified in the Georgia Stormwater Manual. The pond discharges from the property
into an existing ephemeral stream located in the southwest corner of the site. This stream
discharges into a pond due west of the project site. This system is located in the Line Creek
Based on a preliminary analysis, the site will require approximately 150,000 cubic feet in
The following Area Summary table shows the estimated time of concentration, CN values and
The following table shows the reduction of flow into the existing ephemeral channel.
The proposed stormwater runoff will be collected, detained and treated for water quality and
channel protection on-site. This detention will be provided with controlled outfall to the Line
Creek Nature Preserve Pond and ultimately, Line Creek. This release of stormwater for the
proposed site shall not be greater than the pre-developed rate of stormwater runoff leased to
the Points-of-Study for all rainfall events up to the 100-year storm. Based on and limited to
the hydrological data, analysis, and applicability, presented herein, the development with the
proposed systems and structures is deemed not to increase endangerment of life or property

This study presents an analysis of the existing and future traffic operating conditions expected
to result from the proposed The Overlook development to be located on the south side of SR 54
between MacDuff Parkway and Planterra Way in Peachtree City, Georgia. The development
will consist of: approximately 94,954 square feet of retail space; 4,860 square feet of fast food;
and gasoline station/convenience store with 20 fueling positions.
The Overlook development will have access to the external road network via three driveways: a
full movement western driveway on SR 54 along existing Line Creek Drive; a new eastern right-
in/right-out driveway on SR 54; and a full movement driveway on Planterra Way directly
opposite Peachtree City Tennis Center driveway. The Overlook development is expected to be
The existing year 2013 conditions and development’s opening year 2015 (both No-Build and
Build) conditions were evaluated for the surrounding roadway network. Traffic signal warrant
analysis was also performed for the intersection of SR 54 at Line Creek Drive for the 2015 Build
The Overlook development will generate approximately 151 new inbound trips and 116 new
outbound trips during the weekday AM peak hour, and approximately 187 new inbound trips
and 191 new outbound trips during the weekday PM peak hour.
In summary, traffic operations within the study area are not expected to worsen after the
completion of The Overlook development (Build conditions) when compared with the No-Build
conditions. A traffic signal is warranted at the intersection of SR 54 at Line Creek Drive for 2015
Build conditions. Additional improvements are not required to mitigate the impact of The
This study presents an analysis of the existing and future traffic operating conditions expected
to result from the proposed The Overlook development to be located on the south side of SR 54
between MacDuff Parkway and Planterra Way in Peachtree City, Georgia. The development
will consist of: approximately 94,954 square feet of retail space; 4,860 square feet of fast food;
and gasoline station/convenience store with 20 fueling positions.
The Overlook development will have access to the external road network via three driveways: a
full movement western driveway on SR 54 along existing Line Creek Drive; a new eastern right-
in/right-out driveway on SR 54; and a full movement driveway on Planterra Way directly
opposite Peachtree City Tennis Center driveway. The Overlook development is expected to be
The existing year 2013 conditions and development’s opening year 2015 (both No-Build and
Build) conditions were evaluated for the surrounding roadway network. Traffic signal warrant
analysis was also performed for the intersection of SR 54 at Line Creek Drive for the 2015 Build
conditions. Figure 1 shows the site location.
The following key study intersections were identified:
Planterra Way at Peachtree City Tennis Center driveway.
To determine existing traffic conditions for the study intersections and nearby roadways serving
the site, an inventory was made of the major roads in the vicinity of the site. The following is a
SR 54 is a four-lane divided roadway through the study area. SR 54 is classed as an Urban
Principal Arterial in the study area. SR 54 has an east-west orientation and a speed limit of 45
mph. The land uses along SR 54 are primarily commercial with some residential.
MacDuff Parkway is a two-lane roadway with a north-south orientation and a speed limit of
35mph. MacDuff Parkway is classed as a local street. Land use along MacDuff Parkway is
Line Creek Drive is a two-lane roadway with a north-south orientation and a speed limit of
25mph. North of SR 54, Line Creek Drive provides access to an existing shopping complex.
Planterra Way is a two-lane roadway with a north-south orientation and a speed limit of
25mph. Planterra Way is classed as an urban collector. North of SR 54, Planterra Way provides
access to an existing shopping complex. South of SR 54, the land use along Planterra Way is
There are no planned transportation improvements identified within the study area to be
Intersection capacity analyses were performed using procedures in the Transportation
Research Board’s Highway Capacity Manual (HCM), Millennium Edition. Synchro 7 was used to
Operating conditions at intersections are evaluated in terms of Levels of Service (LOS). The
Level of Service for an intersection is based on vehicular delay at the intersection. Levels of
Service A through D are generally considered to be acceptable peak hour operations. Levels of
Service E and F are generally considered to be unacceptable conditions during the peak hour.
Typically, if the intersection is operating at Level of Service E or F in the existing conditions, then
mitigation is developed to maintain the current Level of Service. The Levels of Service criteria
for signalized and unsignalized intersections are shown in Table 1.
Table 1. Levels of Service Delay Criteria
After conducting an evaluation of the existing roadway system, it was determined that capacity
be performed at the key intersections for the weekday AM and PM peak hours.
Weekday AM and PM peak hour turning movement counts were collected on Tuesday,
February 26, 2013, at the study intersections as follows:
Planterra Way at Peachtree City Center driveway.
All turning movement counts were recorded during the weekday morning and evening peak
times, from 7:00-9:00 AM and 4:00-6:00 PM, respectively. The four consecutive 15-minute
interval volumes, summed to produce the highest volume at each intersection, were then
determined. These volumes make up the peak hour traffic volumes for the intersections
counted. Figure 3 shows the existing traffic volumes and Figure 4 shows the existing lane
geometry and traffic control at the study intersections.
Also, twenty-four hour bi-directional counts were collected on Tuesday, February 26, 2013, on
SR 54 and Line Creek Drive. The results of the twenty four counts show the Average Daily Traffic
(ADT) volumes along SR 54 to be approximately 42,100 vehicles. The ADT along Line Creek Drive
The raw traffic count data is included in the Appendix.
Intersection capacity analyses were performed for the study intersections. The results of the
capacity analyses, including the average delay and V/C ratio, for existing conditions (using the
existing traffic counts and the existing intersection geometries) at the study intersections are
presented in Table 2. The capacity analysis printouts are included in the Appendix.
Table 2. Existing Conditions Levels of Service
As seen in Table 2, the study intersections currently operate with acceptable overall Levels of
Service during the weekday AM and PM peak hours with the exception of the intersection of SR
54 at Line Creek Drive during both peak hours. Since the traffic volumes on the sidstreets are
It is important to note that it is not uncommon to have an unsignalized intersection to have an
approach (usually sidestreet) to have an unacceptable Level of Service. This does not mean that
the intersection as a whole is not operating at an acceptable Level of Service.
The Overlook development will consist of: approximately 94,954 square feet of retail space;
4,860 square feet of fast food; and gasoline station/convenience store with 20 fueling positions.
The Overlook development is expected to be completed by the year 2015.
The Overlook development will have access to the external road network via three driveways: a
full movement western driveway on SR 54 along existing Line Creek Drive; a new eastern right-
in/right-out driveway on SR 54; and a full movement driveway on Planterra Way directly
opposite Peachtree City Tennis Center driveway.
The site plan is shown in Figure 5.
The estimated trip generation for The Overlook was developed using the Institute of
Transportation Engineers (ITE) Trip Generation. This is the standard methodology used to
calculate new vehicular trips for new developments. The results of the trip generation are
Typically for mixed-use developments, some reductions are made in the trip generation to
account for the interaction between the land uses within the project. Some interaction is
expected between the commercial land uses, which will reduce the overall trip generation for
the proposed development. These mixed-use reduction percentages were based on ITE Trip
Generation Handbook recommendations for retail to retail land uses.
The trip distribution is the percentage of site traffic that travels on each of the various
roadways to and from a site. The trip distribution was based on the existing traffic volume
patterns in the study area. The trip distribution is shown in Figure 6.
The trip distribution was applied to the AM and PM peak hour site generated trips in order to
develop the AM and PM peak hour site generated volumes at the study intersections. The
distribution percentages illustrated in Figure 6 were applied to the expected trips generated
from the proposed development as shown in Table 3.
The trip generation for this development also includes reduction for pass-by trips. Pass-by trips
are trips already on the roadway network that are diverted to the new development.
Commercial land uses typically have a high percentage of pass-by trips. These trips are reduced
from the total trips generated but are still assigned to the access points. The pass-by
percentages used were based on ITE recommendations for Land Uses 820, 934 and 945.
The estimated project trips at the study intersections during the weekday AM and PM peak
Between the time this study is performed and The Overlook development is built-out and
occupied in the opening year 2015, the traffic volumes on the adjacent roadways are expected
to increase as a result of other developments being constructed both inside and outside the
study area as well as changes in traffic patterns. This growth is called background traffic
growth. This growth can generally be determined by examining historic trends in the vicinity of
the subject site, and by applying those trends to the appropriate roadways.
After analyzing historical traffic data, a growth rate of 3.2% was calculated for the area and
applied to existing traffic counts (from 2013) to determine the appropriate values to use when
No planned transportation improvements were identified within the study area that were to be
The opening year No-Build (without project volumes) traffic volumes for 2015 were developed
by applying a 3.2% per year growth factor to existing traffic from 2013 for two years. The
opening year 2015 No-Build traffic volumes are shown in Figure 8.
The results of the intersection capacity analysis for the No-Build traffic conditions are shown in
Table 4. No-Build Conditions Levels of Service
As seen in Table 4, for the No-Build conditions, the study intersections are expected to operate
with acceptable overall Levels of Service during the weekday AM and PM peak hours, with the
At the intersection of SR 54 at MacDuff Parkway during the AM peak hour;
At the intersection of SR 54 at Line Creek Drive during both peak hours; and
At the intersection of SR 54 at Planterra Way during both peak hours.
Signal timing improvements along the SR 54 coordinated signal system are expected to improve
traffic operating conditions at the two signalized intersections. However, for the purposes of
this traffic study, the signal timings were not changed. Also, at the intersection of SR 54 at Line
Creek Drive, the traffic volumes on the sidstreets are low, and therefore, improvements are not
It is important to note that it is not uncommon to have an unsignalized intersection to have an
approach (usually sidestreet) to have an unacceptable Level of Service. This does not mean that
the intersection as a whole is not operating at an acceptable Level of Service.
The estimated traffic from The Overlook development was added to the No-Build traffic
volumes to represent the traffic expected in the area in the future when the development is
fully complete. The Build traffic volumes are shown in Figure 9 for the opening year 2015.
The results of the intersection capacity analysis for the opening year Build (with project traffic)
Table 5. Build Conditions Levels of Service
As seen in Table 5, for the Build conditions, the study intersections are expected to operate
with acceptable overall Levels of Service during the weekday AM and PM peak hours, with the
At the intersection of SR 54 at MacDuff Parkway during the AM peak hour; and
At the intersection of SR 54 at Planterra Way during both peak hours.
Signal timing improvements along the SR 54 coordinated signal system are expected to improve
traffic operating conditions at the two signalized intersections. However, for the purposes of
this traffic study, the signal timings were not changed.
geometry and traffic control at the study intersections.
Traffic signal warrant analysis was performed for the intersection of SR 54 at Line Creek Drive
for the 2015 Build conditions in order to determine whether installing a traffic signal is
warranted. The Manual on Uniform Traffic Control Devices (MUTCD), published by the Federal
Highway Administration, lists eight warrants that may be considered when determining if an
intersection should be signalized. The warrants are:
The MUTCD states that “The satisfaction of a traffic signal warrant or warrants shall not in itself
require the installation of a traffic control signal.” However, one or more warrants should be
met before a signal is installed.
For the purposes of this traffic study, Warrants 1, 2 and 3 were evaluated based on GDOT’s
“100% criteria” and not to include right turning traffic on the sidestreets in the analysis.
The 24-hour ADT count data on SR 54 as well as on Line Creek Drive were used to develop the
traffic volumes for traffic signal warrant analysis. The 3.2% per year growth rate was applied to
the 24-hour ADT counts and the site generated trips were added to develop the Build traffic
volumes at the intersection of SR 54 at Line Creek Drive. It is noted that the right turning traffic
on the sidestreets were not included. The Build traffic volumes are shown in Table 6 for the
Table 6. Traffic Signal Warrant Analysis Traffic Volumes
Table 7 summarizes the results of the traffic signal warrant analysis conducted.
As seen in Table 10, for the Build conditions, the intersection meets Warrant 1B (Eight Hour -
Interruption of Continuous Flow), and Warrant 2 (Four Hour Volume). The results of the traffic
signal warrant analysis is included in the Appendix.

approximately 94,954 square feet of retail space; 4,860 square feet of fast food; and gasoline

It is noted that the intersections of SR 54 at MacDuff Parkway and at Planterra Way are
expected to operate at unacceptable Levels of Service. However, signal timing improvements
along the SR 54 coordinated signal system are expected to improve traffic operating conditions
